Dear Holly Anderton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code &
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section
requirements; staff qualifications.
Description
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On an unknown date within the last few weeks, Staff 1, Staff 2,
and Staff 3 were neglecting other kids in the home as kids were
vaping and smoking in a room with the staff. All five of the children
reside in the home, but it is unclear which children were involved.
It is unknown if they were smoking and vaping marijuana or
nicotine.
Investigation Complainant/Staff 7 was interviewed via phone on 2/5/2024.
He was unable to provide any further information about the
allegations and reported gaining the information from Youth C,
Friday night around 10:00 pm. Complainant/Staff 7 was
interviewed again face to face at the facility on 2/8/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported Youth C
informed him Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 6 were allowing youth to
vape in the den on the unit. Complainant/Staff 7 also reported
never having any concerns of this behavior because he never
smelled smoke in the den nor observed any staff or youth smoking
in the den. Youth C reported to him this had occurred in the past
few weeks.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/5/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
knowing of the allegations. She reported there was no camera in
the den, but the facility is in the process of installing a camera in
the den and the den is closed to youth until the installation of the
2

camera. Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 6 are not to be alone with youth
until this investigation is completed. Staff 2 had informed
Administrator last Wednesday (1/31/24) that Staff 2 had observed
Staff 1 smoke a “black and mild” with Youth A during an outing to
Meijer. Administrator asked Youth A about this, and Youth A
denied Staff 1 purchased the “black and mild” for Youth A. Staff 2
also reported to Administrator Youth A asked her to buy a “black
and mild” for him during the same outing, but Staff 2 declined.
Administrator reported Staff 1 will be terminated, and Staff 6 quit
after the allegations came to light. Staff 2 provided text messages
she received from Staff 6 in which Staff 6 doesn’t trust Staff 2
because Staff 2 doesn’t have Staff 1’s back. Administrator
reported having concerns about Staff 1’s boundaries with the
youth over the past couple of weeks and had begun looking into
these concerns. Staff 1 was being watched over the past week
and his actions were reviewed on the video recordings but nothing
inappropriate was observed. Administrator reported being told by
Staff 7 that Staff 1 had called Staff 7 and told Staff 7 Staff 1 had
purchased a “black and mild” for Youth A during the outing to
Meijers. Staff 1 asked Staff 7 what he should do about buying the
“black and mild”. Administrator was interviewed again face to
face at the facility on 2/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. She reported the outing Staff 1, Staff 2, and Youth A took
to Meijer was not approved by a supervisor and no one else knew
where they had gone. The second outing to Meijer that day with
Youth B and Youth D was also not approved. Administrator was
interviewed again face to face at the facility on 2/13/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported outings need
supervisor permission and there is a list of requirements for youth
to have a “store run”. A risk assessment must be completed, and
the youth must be making progress. She reported the “store run”
with Youth A, Staff 1 and Staff 2 was approved but the second
“store run” the same day with Youth B, Youth D, and Staff 1 was
not approved. Permission to use personal cars is never approved
and Staff 1 used his personal car for both “store runs”.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/5/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He denied the
allegations of smoking marijuana or cigarettes with Staff 1 during
any of the seven trips to his father’s house conducted by Staff 1.
He reported visiting with his father seven times during the last two
months and the drive takes two hours one way. Youth A reported
never observing Staff 1 smoking anything and doesn’t believe
Staff 1 would do something like smoke in front of youth. Youth A
denied ever smoking a “black and mild”. Youth A admitted to
smoking marijuana but reported getting the marijuana from school
3

and not any staff. Youth A denied vaping with any staff and
suggested not spending any time with Staff 2 and very little time
with Staff 6. His prior support staff has been Staff 1 whom he feels
the safest around.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/5/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B denied
any staff offering him a vape or black and mild nor has he heard of
any staff smoking with youth at the facility. Youth B reported he
would be surprised if that had happened. Youth B also reported
smoking marijuana with a friend from school approximately 5 to 6
months ago, but it was off site from the campus. Youth B denied
any of the youth in the program presently are smoking marijuana
with staff and no staff has used a vape during an outing. He feels
safe at the facility and had several staff he can process emotional
issues with.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/5/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C
reported Youth A told him about smoking at Youth A’s father’s
home and on the way there. Youth C reported Staff 1 is doing
something that will get him fired but had no more information
about what this action might be, but she did inform Complainant
about it. Youth C reported telling Complainant about staff vaping
with youth because “staff must be bringing the youth vapes
because the youth are suspended from school and there is no
other way to get the vapes”. Youth C admitted to never observing
youth smoking a vape with staff and the only time she observed a
youth smoking a vape was when she was inside the house and
observed Youth A letting smoke out of his mouth approximately
100 yards away as he was leaving for an off campus group. Youth
C believes staff are smoking because Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, and
Staff 6 will go into the den, locking the door behind them and only
come out an “hour or two later”. When they come back out of the
room, they are laughing so they must be smoking something.
Youth C reported another incident of vaping occurred during an
outing when all of the youth with the exception of Youth C were
vaping during the ride. Youth A, Youth B, Youth D, and Youth E
had a blanket pulled over their heads and they were vaping while
Youth C was sitting in the front seat. Youth C reported knowing
this information because these youth are “not smart at lying”.
Youth C is able to identify the vape pen because of the outline it
makes in the other youth’s pants pockets. Youth C also reported
Youth A, Youth B, Youth D, and Youth E get their vapes from
school and only Youth A smokes marijuana in his vape because it
smells “like dead skunk”. Youth C was unable to recall when she
4

smelled “dead skunk”. Youth C admitted to never observing staff
giving a vape to the other youth, but they must have because the
youth were suspended and had no other way to get a vape.
Youth D refused to be interviewed at the facility on 2/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Youth E refused to be interviewed at the facility on 2/5/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/5/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported never
observing staff or youth smoke on campus but that she was
present at the outing to Meijers when Staff 1 purchased and
allowed Youth A to smoke a “black and mild”. Staff 1, Staff 2, and
Youth A were together on the outing when Staff 2 observed Staff 1
pass a cigarette to Youth A. Youth A smoked half of the cigarette.
Staff 2 reported asking Staff 1 about allowing this action and
having Staff 1 inform Staff 2 that Youth A was stressed out and
needed to smoke to relax. Youth A asked Staff 2 to purchase a
“black and mild” but Staff 2 refused, so Staff 1 purchased the
“black and mild”. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 took his own car which
staff are not to do and reported “someone gave him permission”.
Staff 2 did not know if Youth A smoked the “black and mild” once
back on campus. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 took Youth B and Youth
D on another outing to Meijers later and bought Youth A a “Rello”
to smoke. Youth D informed Staff 2 of this purchase by Staff 1. In
regard to the allegations of staff using substances on campus,
Staff 2 reported observing Staff 6 with a vape in her hands in the
bathroom and den area on the unit. She also reported Staff 1 and
Staff 6 have talked about smoking marijuana while working and
smelling marijuana when getting into Staff 1’s car for an outing.
Staff 2 reported Youth A told her, Youth A will smoke marijuana
with Staff 1 when going to Youth A’s father’s home for a visit.
When confronting Staff 1 about this information, both Youth A and
Staff 1 began to laugh saying it’s not true. Staff 2 reported never
observing Staff 6 smoking with any youth but reported Staff 6
would share “sex tapes” with staff on campus. Staff 6 would share
a video of a man’s body and asked Staff 2 to share videos of Staff
2’s man’s body. Staff 2 reported Staff 1 and Staff 6 will sit next to
each other during their shift and play on their phones while talking
rather than engaging with the youth. Staff 2 reported when Staff 6
showed Staff 2 the video it was off campus at Meijer. Staff 2
reported Staff 1 sent text messages to Staff 2 asking Staff 2 to lie
about the incident at Meijers with the “black and mild” and Staff 6
told Staff 2 that Staff 2 was wrong for not having Staff 1’s back in
5

this investigation. Staff 2 was interviewed again face to face at
the facility on 2/9/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker.
She reported taking Youth A to his father’s home only to find
Youth A’s father not at home. Youth A is reported to have told
Staff 2 that Staff 1 always comes inside the home, watches
television and smokes with Youth A while they wait for Youth A’s
father. Youth A reported to Staff 2 that Staff 1 will stop several
places on the trip so both Youth A and Staff 1 can smoke outside
of the facility van. Staff 2 reported Staff 5 was present during this
outing.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Supervisor 1
reported being informed Youth C told Complainant/Staff 7 that
Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 6 were allowing youth to vape in the den
room on the unit. After receiving this information, Supervisor 1
contacted Administrator to begin developing a safety plan. The
safety plan involved Staff 1, Staff 2, and Staff 6 are not allowed to
be alone with the youth nor transport youth and the den room will
be closed.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
being informed of the allegations by Staff 2 and Administrator. She
reported having no concerns with Staff 2 and Staff 6 but has had
to address boundary issues with Staff 1 when he began to touch
Youth D on the shoulder while playing tag.
Supervisor 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported on
Thursday last week (2/1/24) having an encounter with Youth A
because Youth A was smoking a black and mild on the porch of
the unit. Youth A gave the lighter to Supervisor 3 but refused to
give up the “black and mild” saying it was his. Youth A informed
Supervisor 3, that Youth A was upset over not having a visit with
Youth A’s father and needed the “black and mild” to relax. Youth A
informed Supervisor 3 that Youth A found the “black and mild”
laying on the ground when on an outing at Meijers and Supervisor
3 should know that Staff 1 didn’t buy the “black and mild” for Youth
A. Supervisor 3 reported having no concerns with Staff 2 and Staff
6 but having some concerns with Staff 1. Staff 1 is requested by
the youth more than other staff and the youth report Staff 1 is a
favorite staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at his home on 2/8/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 began the
6

interview by denying the allegations of purchasing a “black and
mild” for Youth A and denying allowing Youth A to smoke while
under Staff 1’s supervision. Staff 1 admitted to smoking marijuana
and “black and mild” on occasions. He denied smoking any
marijuana when taking Youth A, to Youth A’s father’s home and
never taking Youth A to Staff 1’s house. After reporting Youth A,
grabbed a cigarette from Staff 1’s hand, Staff 1 began to change
his report. Staff 1 reported Youth A was begging Staff 2 to buy a
“black and mild” for Youth A and when Staff 2 refused, Staff 1 “not
thinking” brought the “black and mild” for Youth A. This was after
Youth A finished the cigarette Staff 1 was smoking. Staff 1 also
believed he was helping Youth A out because Youth A was
stressed-out and needed to relax. Staff 1 reported becoming “a
little too friendly” with youth and making a huge mistake with the
cigarette and “black and mild”. He also reported Staff 2 just
watched Youth A smoke and if she had told Staff 1 not to buy the
“black and mild”, he would not have purchased it. Staff 1 reported
never seeing or hearing of staff giving any substances to youth.
Staff 6 used to vape but not on campus. Staff 1 was interviewed
again via phone on 2/13/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. Staff 1 denied purchasing a “Rello” (tobacco product) for
Youth B or Youth D. Staff 1 was unable to recall what Youth B and
Youth D bought at Meijers. Staff 1 denied ever going into Youth
A’s father’s home and smoking with Youth A during the trip to the
father’s home. Staff 1 then denied taking any youth on an outing
without a supervisor’s permission.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/12/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 5 reported being
present when Staff 2, Staff 5, and Youth A went to Youth A’s
father’s home for a visit. When they got to the home, they found
Youth A’s father not present, so they contacted the supervisor for
instructions and were told to go get something to eat and return.
While at the restaurant, Youth A’s father contacted them, and they
drove to the home. Youth A offered both Staff 2 and Staff 5 to wait
in the house, but they refused to enter the house. Staff 5 reported
never hearing Youth A say Staff 1 would smoke with Youth A
during a visit in the van, on the way or in the house.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/13/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported having no
knowledge of the reason for the interview and when provided the
allegations she reported not being sure why she was involved.
Staff 6 denied using any substances or smoking with youth and
suggested she is the one staff who would get on the youth for
vaping. Staff 6 reported vaping but never bringing a vape to
7

campus and never offering a vape to the youth. Staff 6 reported
Staff 4 told Staff 6 that Staff 4 was vaping with Youth A and Youth
B in the den once and that Staff 4 only “hit” the vape once. Staff 6
denied showing any inappropriate pictures on her phone to other
staff.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 2/13/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported vaping in her
car on campus and having the youth seeing her once. She also
reported the youth make jokes about her vaping, but she never
vaped with the youth or anywhere else on campus. Staff 4 spoke
with Administrator and was told she would need to be off campus
if she was going to vape. Staff 4 reported catching Youth A with
vapes in the unit and taking the vape away from Youth A. A critical
incident report was written on this incident.
Documents Reviewed:
Human Resources file for Staff 6 was reviewed.
Documentation indicates Staff 6 was hired in April 2023 and had
no disciplinary action documented in her file. Staff 6 was current
on training.
Human Resources file for Staff 4 was reviewed.
Documentation indicates Staff 4 was hired in October 2023 and
had no disciplinary action documented in her file. Staff 4 was
current on training.
Human Resources file for Staff 2 was reviewed.
Documentation indicates Staff 2 was hired in December 2023 and
had no disciplinary action documented in her file. Staff 2 was
current on training and completed the mandated reporter training
on 12/28/2023.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed.
Documentation indicates Staff 1 was hired in November 2023 and
terminated on 2/4/2024 for misconduct. There were one
disciplinary action documents in the file for Staff 1 which resulted
in his termination. Corrective Action and Improvement Plan
(CAIP) dated 2/4/24. This document outlines the reasons for this
plan as violation of safety, insubordination, violation of policies or
procedures, and misconduct. It also indicates the level of the CAIP
is termination of employment. Staff 1’s behaviors leading to this
CAIP are documented as, purchasing illegal substances for a
youth, and then smoking with the same youth, entering, and
staying in a youth’s bedroom alone which Staff 1 was already
8

spoken to about this being an inappropriate action, and attempting
to have another staff report events in an investigation dishonestly.
Staff 1 is documented as violating a Michigan Law prohibiting an
adult of furnishing substances to minors, violating policy and
procedures about maintaining appropriate boundaries on tobacco
use on and off campus.
Text messages between Staff 1 and Staff 2 dated 2/3/24
beginning at 12:33 pm. Staff 2 informed Staff 1 that she knows
about the investigation and Staff 6 had just called Staff 2 to inform
Staff 2 about the investigation. Staff 2 acknowledged that she is
not to talk about the investigation with anyone. Staff 2 reports
doing nothing wrong and informs Staff 1 that Staff 1 better hope
he doesn’t get told on. Staff 1 tells Staff 2 that the only place they
went to on the outing was the dollar store to which Staff 2 replies
“that’s lying”. Staff 2 informs Staff 1 that she must protect herself
and Staff 2 had nothing to do with Staff 1 buying a “black and
mild” for Youth A. Staff 2 also informs Staff 1 that she will tell the
truth about the situation. Staff 2 ends the conversation by stating
“we all need to tell the truth”.
Text messages from Staff 6 to Staff 4 dated 2/12/2024. In this
text message, Staff 6 informs Staff 4 that because Staff 4 is
ignoring Staff 6’s phone calls, Staff 6 is going to tell on Staff 4 for
vaping with the youth in the program.
Email from Administrator with a statement from Staff 6 dated
2/14/2024. The attachment is the text from Staff 6 to Staff 4 and
the narrative in the email is Staff 4’s response. Staff 4 admits to
taking breaks and vaping in her car in the past and once the youth
observed her vaping in the car. Staff 4 reported sharing the
incident with Staff 2 and Staff 6. Staff 4 reported Staff 2 and Staff
6 told Staff 4 not to be worried about it because Staff 4 didn’t vape
in front of the youth. Staff 4 requests of Administrator if Staff 4
could have addressed this incident in a better way.
D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Program Procedure Tobacco Free
Environment Policy dated 5/21/2018. This document outlines
that the entire campus is to be entirely tobacco free. Staff are
prohibited from any tobacco use while with youth both on campus
and off campus. Tobacco use is prohibited in all owned/leased
vehicles and employees are prohibited from any tobacco use
when transporting youth. This policy covers all forms of tobacco
including cigarettes, cigars, pipes, vaping devices, and chewing
tobacco.
9

Activities off-campus approval list covering 12/1/23 to
1/31/24. This document outlines approved outing for youth during
the month of December and January. Two outing occurred on
1/31/24 involving Staff 1. The first activity(outing) has a destination
of Dollar Tree and lists Staff 1 and Staff 2 along with Youth A and
takes place from 6:00 to 6:30 pm. The second outing has Staff 1
along with Youth B and Youth D and has a destination of Meijer,
occurring from 8:30 to 9:00 pm.
D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Program Procedure Youth
Development Specialist Procedures dated 2/2022. This
document outlines the responsibilities of Youth Development
Specialist (DYS) staff. The YDS staff are to provide a positive and
supportive adult figure, with a non-judgmental approach to
supporting the youth. The staff’s interactions with youth must be
trauma responsive which means no horseplay is allowed. The
YDS staff are to maintain clear and appropriate boundaries which
involves maintaining a separation between work and family.
Unusual event for Youth A dated 1/31/24 at 9:30 pm and
written by Supervisor 3. This document outlines Youth A had
possession of a black and mild and was smoking it on the porch of
the unit. Supervisor 3 attempted to verbally deescalate Youth A
but Youth A refused to give up the black and mild and smoked it
until finished. Youth A did give Supervisor 3 the lighter and when
asked where Youth A obtained the black and mild, Youth A
reported finding it on the ground during a store run with Staff 1.
Youth A also reported Staff 1 had no part in giving the black and
mild to Youth A.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is
significant evidence that supports Staff 1 had engaged in
inappropriate behaviors when purchasing a tobacco product and
allowing Youth A to smoke a cigarette while on an outing.
Evidence also indicates Staff 4 was using a vaping product while
on the grounds of the campus. Staff 1 was also confirmed by
MDHHS.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2023C0000459: CAP approved 8/22/23.
2023C0000595; CAP approved 9/18/23.
2023C0000393; CAP approved 6/14/23.
2022C0228004; CAP approved 10/19/22.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law;
Section development of plan required.
Description
10

(1) The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA 238,
MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During the course of this investigation, it was discovered that Staff
2 became aware of Staff 1 providing tobacco products to Youth A
on 1/31/2024 but failed to make an abuse and neglect report until
2/3/2024.
Investigation Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/5/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported observing
Staff 1 allowing Youth A to smoke half of Staff 1’s cigarette and
then purchasing a black and mild from Meijers for Youth A on
1/31/2024. Staff 2 reported not knowing the process for making a
report and felt very fearful to make such a report. She reported
keeping the information to herself until speaking to Staff 3 and
Staff 4 a couple of days later. Staff 2 finally spoke with Supervisor
2 who helped her complete the reporting process on Saturday,
February 3, 2024.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/8/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being aware
of the allegations because she is a supporter of Staff 2 who
informed her of the allegations, she heard about the allegations of
Staff 1 supplying substances to Youth A. Staff 3 reported not
knowing if the allegations are true or not true. Staff 3 reported
telling Staff 2, Staff 2 needed to make a report of the allegations
and went over the process of reporting incidents.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 2/8/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 4 reported being
informed of the allegations by Staff 2 and feeling scared about
reporting the incident. Staff 4 reported telling Staff 2 she would
support her emotionally and Staff 2 needed to make a report of
the incident. Staff 2 informed Staff 4 that Staff 2 didn’t know how
to report an incident and would be speaking to her supervisor
about reporting. Staff 4 reported Staff 2 talked to her about this
incident on the Saturday following the incident.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
2/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported
Staff 2 came to her around 10pm on Saturday February 3, 2024
and appeared very upset. Supervisor 2 helped Staff 2 through the
reporting process and Staff 2 told her Staff 2 didn’t know who to
11

speak to about the incident and reporting process. Supervisor 2
reported Staff 2 had been trained on being a mandated reporter
and should have made the report within 24-hours.
Documents Reviewed:
D.A. Blodgett St. John’s Program Procedure Child Abuse and
Neglect Reporting Procedure dated 7/2008. This document
outlines staff’s actions when suspected child abuse or neglect is
found. The first step indicates staff are to “report the suspicion to
CPS immediately”. If the suspected abuse or neglect occurs with a
staff, it “will be investigated immediately”. Staff are to report their
suspicions to their Supervisor, HR Director, or Program Manager
immediately.
Human Resources file for Staff 2 was reviewed.
Documentation indicates Staff 2 was hired in December 2023 and
had no disciplinary action documented in her file. Staff 2 was
current on training and completed the mandated reporter training
on 12/28/2023.
Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is
evidence that supports Staff 2 failed to follow policy and report
suspected abuse and neglect within the required time frame. Staff
2 knew of the situation on 1/31/2024 and did not make a report
until 2/3/2024.
Conclusion Violation Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
